awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type I: Collaborative Research: Interconnects Beyond Cu
awd_abstract_narration:
When electrons move through wires, they are scattered by vibrating atoms and wire imperfections. This scattering is the source of the electrical resistance and results in power consumption. For the wires used in modern electronics (interconnects) this is already a bottleneck to computing performance and is worsening as the wires (along with the transistors) are made smaller.  The aim of this program is to make the wires so small (<< 10-nm in width and height) and so structurally perfect that quantum size effects arise and the electrons can travel in a ballistic fashion without scattering. This can result in orders of magnitude improvements in resistance and computing energy efficiency and enable a revolution in electronics. In addition to the societal benefit of improved computing, the program will support education and research at the undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral levels at four institutions, Columbia University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and the University of Central Florida. The outreach effort will include: (1) The Harlem Schools Partnership (HSP) for STEM education at CU, (2) MIT's Materials Day for industry outreach, (3) the Discovery Engineering program for high-school girls at RPI, and (4) the techCAMP "Future of Information" at UCF.

To achieve its goal of ballistic conduction in metallic nanowires, the project will include the preparation and atomic scale characterization of single crystal metallic films and lines as well as experimental measurement of electron transport behavior, with ruthenium as the metal of choice for the initial studies. The stability of the metallic lines will also be investigated, since this is critical to the reliability of interconnects in computing systems. A theoretical and computational physics modeling effort will aim to provide a quantitative understanding of ballistic transport in the size and defect limits, and serve to identify preferred metals for ballistic conductance of interconnects for future efforts. The computational models and codes developed will be made available on the Nanohub (https://nanohub.org/). The project will additionally provide a proof-of-principle demonstration of how the proposed metallic conductors can be fabricated for technology implementation by the semiconductor industry.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed metallic interconnects beyond copper for energy efficient computing systems.  With regard to intellectual merit, epitaxial films were fabricated by sputter deposition at elevated temperatures with post-deposition annealing for electrical resistivity studies. With these films, it was demonstrated that the surface scattering could be reversibly modified from primarily diffusive to primarily specular for buried ruthenium/dielectric interfaces.  It was also shown that highly ordered Ru(0001) surfaces can be stable in laboratory air exposure, as evidenced by low energy electron diffraction patterns of the surface. In addition, fabrication of single crystal Co(0001), epitaxial bicrystal Cu(111), and  epitaxial, porous polycrystal Ru(0001) films by electrodeposition on ruthenium/sapphire, specifically Ru(0001)/(0001)Al2O3, seed layers was accomplished.  In doing so, proof-of-principle demonstration of electrodeposition of fully dense epitaxial cobalt and copper metals at thicknesses relevant for back end of line in silicon technology was demonstrated. However, the chemistries explored for ruthenium were not suitable for deposition of a fully dense epitaxial layer. Electrodeposition is a room-temperature or near room-temperature deposition method that is compatible with the thermal budget constraints of back-end-of-line (BEOL) in silicon technology.

Further, it was shown that defects in relaxed epitaxial vacuum deposited Ru films include misfit and threading dislocations, stacking faults and deformation twins, and a detailed energetic analysis of their formation was provided. It was shown that the stability of Ru nanowires has a strong dependence on crystallographic orientation and an orientation with especially high morphological stability was determined. Ruthenium nanowires were fabricated in 5 nm and 10 nm thick films with widths down to 13 nm and lengths are short as 35 nm to experimentally explore the limits of ballistic conduction.

Under this project, an electron transport model was developed based on a tight-binding approach that allows conductivity to be computed for structures comprising large ensembles of atoms (105-106), scales linearly with system size and can incorporate defects. In addition to computation of electronic transport, the model also determines the total energy of the crystal including phonon energetics. This enables the calculation of electron-phonon scattering and potentially another mechanism for size-dependent electron scattering.

 With regard to broader impacts, in addition to contribution to science and technology for development of computing systems hardware, students were trained and have found employment in US industry.
